div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,548] ALEXANDRIA, Wednesday, JULY 18, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS.
div.p: CAIRO-KHARTOUM SUMMER MAIL SERVICE.
Commencing from 1st of April, 1906, until further notice.

Sleeping and Dining Cars.–- During the month of April Sleeping and Dining Cars trains leave Cairo for Luxor on Wednesday, Mondays and Saturdays at 6:30 p.m., and Luxor for Cairo on Sundays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 6.30 p.m.

From 1st of May 1906, these trains will be suppressed, byt Dining and Sleeping Cars will be attached to the ordinary night Trains from Cairo and Luxor three times a week, on the same above mentioned days.

div.head: THE LESSONS OF THE MANEUVERS.
div.p: Through the Naval Manœuvres ended a fortnight ago and though a number of correspondents have described what they saw the public will have to wait for their history until the Admiralty's report is issued. In the meantime, though only provisional judgments can be formed on moat of the questions connected with the operations, there are one or two pointa aa to which opinions farce themselves upon the mind of observer., and some of these are worth noting, eject, of forage, to reconsideration when the whole of the facts become known. The theme of the macoeaviwwua war between two Naval Powers, Red and Bine, of whom Red had more than twelve tore of Blue. Bine being hope - leally the weaker fore was expected to attempt, by the attack upon Red seaborne trade, to bring about such a dispersion of the Red forces as to give himself a thane of an engagement against some isolated portion of the Red ivories, presumably dispersed for the protection of Red's trade. In order to make the conditions of trade resemble those of war, Red trade was represented by snob merchant ships as consented to take part in the game on their homeward or outward voyages from or to Gibraltar. A bunch of trade routes was defined, which ran up from Cape St. Viooent along the oat of Portugal and Spain and branched off in the Bay of Biaoay to Milford Haven and the Channel the Red Fleet started from Baglish ports, the Bine from Queenstown and Berehiven. Bine appears to have well understood that Red could anticipate him if any part of the area from which includes the Western entrances to the Irish See, the Bristol Channel, and the English Channel, and also in the Bay of Biscay. He therefore took his main forces both of battleships and cruisers ont into the Atlantic and steamed outside the area this forbidden to him and then south-eastward towards the Spanish coast. There on his arrival he seems for a time, perhaps for twenty-four hours, to have been able to moleit trade. What degree of damage he did can be estimated only when it became known how many groups of trading ships passed along the routes, and what proportion of them were molested by Blue warships. The Red Command ier-in-Chief, Admiral Wilson, was not for a moment induced to disperse his forces. He kept the Channel Fieet together and had the Mediterranean Fleet kept together. So soon as he was snare that Bine had left his porta and gone south he moved southwards, while the Mediterranean Fleet was moved northwards so soon as it was clear that the Bine forces had not gone sooth to come n on the trade routes behind it. But the Blue Admiral divided his greatly inferior force, with the result that one fraction was ought between the two Red Fleets, and driven by the Mediterranean Fleet into the jaws of ,the Channel Fleet, and that the main body of the Blue Battle Fleet was found by the Channel Float and chased into the English Channel, which for the purpose of the attack on trade was on the board. The Blue Cruiser Squadron was also caught by a superior Red force and suffered fêtions loss of ships. Then the Red squadrons of battleships and croisera swept up and down along the trade routes on a front of something like, a hundred miles, combing the sea for Blue men of war. Had hostilities untinned a few days longer it seems likely that the whole of the Blue fore would have been destroyed. Suoh seems to be the general outline of what took place, though it is an outline based upon incomplete information and may require to be modified. The chief point to be borne in mind about the scheme of the manœuvres is that Red was if every class of vessel more than twice as strong as Blue, though in speed the Blue Squadrons had a slight advantage. If therefore we are outroot in supposing that Admiral Wilson in a week rushed the Blue forces, and in another week wand have annihilated them, and that Red's trade, therefore, could not have suffered very serious damage, the moral to be drawn must be that if Great Britain were engaged in a war against a single naval Power whose naval forgoes had less than half the numerical strength of the British Navy, and if the British Navy were commanded by an admiral as strong as Sir Arthur Wilson, while the enemy's Navy was no better handled than the Blue Fleet, then British trade would not he subjected to very severe or onrushing losses and the British Navy would in due time assert tokomak of the sea. But that is not more than the oonDtry has a right to expect. Indeed, it is rather disappointing. No nappies that the nation keeps a Navy on the Two Power standard to be able to congratulate itself that its trade can be efficiently protected against the attack of one Power. It would have been more interesting to have bad the experiment made in conditions giving Bine a rather better thane, as would have been the case it Red had been to Bine not as five to two bat as three to two. For this reason we are not inclined to attach much importance to what may be called the political theme of the manœuvres or to any inferences that could be drawn from them as to the relative strength of navies. Nelson's saying that "only numbers can annihilate" implies that the side which has the number is not properly handled unless it does annihilate the enemy. ("Morning Post")

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Yesterday's plague bulletin records a fatal ease at Port Said. No cases are reported today.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The mail from Europe, viil Brindisi and Port Said, will be delivered at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 4.45 p.m. to-day.

div.head: San Stefano Casino.
div.p: To-morrow there will be a grand vocal and instrumental concert with an entirely new programme. The opening of the Casino Theatre will take place on Saturday.

div.head: Ministry of Justice.
div.p: It is stated that the Ministry of Justice has decided to create a fourth inspectorship to the Committee of Judicial Surveillance, which will be filled by a British barrister, Mr. Fox.

div.head: Saved from Drowning.
div.p: A Bedouin, who was bathing yesterday to the east of the Khedivah Mother's Palace, was carried out to sea and would inevitably have , been drowned had not a coast-guardsman, who . realiced the danger, got a life saving apparatus ' out and brought him safely ashore.

div.head: Murder.
div.p: A native of Jureis, near Manfalont, was murdered while lying asleep in his field two or three days ago. The markai authorities promptly opened an enquiry on the spot and succeeded in establishing the identity of the ] murderer, who, when arrested, made a statement inculpating three other men.

div.head: The Denishwai Affair.
div.p: The documents of the Denishwai case, including the sentence, are now being translated under the supervision of Judge Bond, vice-president of the Native Court of Appeal, who was one of the judges of the Special Court. After the translations have been completed the documents will be sent to London.

div.head: Tram Accident
div.p: A native boy entered a tram near the Customs yesterday without paying for his ticket On his fare being required, he attempted to evade payment by jumping out of the moving tram. His galabieh appears to have caught as he jumped and to have swung him against the wheels, which crushed his left arm. He was immediately removed to hospital.

div.head: Anglo-Oriental College Association.
div.p: The annual dinner of the Mohamedan ADglo- Oriental College Association (Aligarh) was held last week at the Hotel Cecil. Sir Charles Lyall, who presided, announced that several substantial gifts had resulted from the visit of the Prince and Princess of Wales to India, and Sir Thomas Raleigh, speaking of a visit which he had paid to the college, testified to its great value in turning oat for the public service men who were not mere machines but could thick for themselves.

div.head: New Employment Registry.
div.p: The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head: PESONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: T. H. Prince and Princess Hussein Paoba Kamel and Princess Kadria Hussein are leaving for Europe this afternoon by the North German Lloyd steamer.
Lieut. C. A. M. Furnell, R G.A., came down to Alexandria from Cairo yesterday to takeover command of the detachment of Royal Garrison Artillery stationed here.
Mr H. B'omfield, Inspector to the Public Lands Department, Ministry of Finance, has returned to Cairo from leave.
Dr. Phillips returned to Cairo after three months' leave of absence on Sunday.

div.head: NATAL SENSATION. REPORTED MASSACRE OF ZULUS.

div.p: A sensation has been caused by reports of the massacres' Zulus by native levies in the Mome valley and the decapitation of the corpse of Bambaata.
The Natal Government admits that the latter was done for the purpose of identification, but affirms that operations were :or ducted with unexampled humanity. (Ueuter)

div.head:
THE SALISBURY DIASTER
CAUSE OF DERAILMENT.

div.p: The inquest on the Salisbury disaster of the 1st instant showed that the train rounded the curve at seventy miles en hour instead of the prescribed thirty. (Reuter)
The Minister of War has appointed General Pavloff president of the commission which has been formed to enquire into the disaffection of the Army. (Reuter)
The police have gone on strike and are marching through the streets compelling comrades to join them. Their claims are economic, not political. (Reuter)
The policeman have gone on strike for economic reasons. (Haras)
The Consul at San Salvador reports that peace has been concluded through the friendly J intervention of Presidents Roosevelt and j Porfirio Diaz. (Havas)
Cricket. Lancashire beat Somerset by an innings and 143 runs.(Reuter)

div.head: FISHING BOAT DISASTER.
div.p: CAPSIZED OFF ALEXANDRIA.
SIX MEN DROWNED
News reached Alexandria yesterday of a shipping disaster off the Abonkir coast by which six men lost their lives.

It appears that on the night of Monday a flotilla of Italian fishing boats was returning to harbor, when one of their number, with a crew of ten, capsized, owing to the high sea and strong wind that prevailed at the time. The accident was unobserved by the other vessel', an! it was only on their return to harbor that the smack was missed.

Meantime a tragedy had been enacted. Of the crew of ten, two were on deck when the boat capsized, one at the helm and the other on the look-out, the rest being asleep below. Three of the latter were awakened by the shock and managed to scramble on deck, when's they clambered on to the helm, which had become detached from the boat, along with the two other men. The five other members of the crew sank with this boat, and it is believed that their bodies are still in the vessel.

The five men managed to remain floating on the helm tilldaybreak, when a big wave came and swept them into the water. Four were able to swim to an inlet, but the other was too extant- e 1 and gave up the straggle for life. The four men were afterwards picked up by a coastguard boat which was sent out to their rescue and the body of the other was also recovered by the coastguards. The latter was brought into town by h>s more fortunate comrades and now lies in hospital, for the usual post-mortem examination.
The boat capsized in 13 fathoms of water, about a mile from the Montazah coast.

The following are the names and ages of the members of the orew who were drowned :— De Vincsan Domenico (13), Vinoensc Giovanni Livineo (40), Albatista FranceBoo (II), Stoia Giovannini (41), Barlamo Giuseppe (47), Camporiale Loerado (50). The latter is the One whose body has been recovered. The four whose lives were saved are : La FagiaCollenso (20), Lasso Giaoiuto (26), SalovanB'ni Nioo- lanzi (60), àoansa Sugea (27).

div.head: THE PATH AN REFLOATED.
div.p: Suez, Tuesday.

The 8 3. Pathan, which was ashore in the Canal, was refloated yesterday afternoon with the assistance if the tog Robust, which subsequently towed her to Suez. This vessel is now mcored in the North Basin, as she sustained some damage and is leaking.

div.head: THE SERSINA ENQUIRY.
div.p: We understand that the enquiry held has so far failed to establish the fact that the native found dead at Sersina on the 13th ult. Was killed, as alleged by certain natives, by a soldier of the mounted infantry patrol pent to residue the officers who had been attacked by the villagers of Danishwai.
The Egyptian Government is taking up the matter and making further enquiries.

The authorities of the Army of Occupation who are inquiring into the Sersina affray have decided to make a second post-mortem examination of the body of the native who was killed. The body was exhumed yesterday in the presence of a medical officer of the Army of Occupation and the official physician of the Native Tribunals, who will examine the body.

div.head: COTTON WORM.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has communicated to the Press a note giving the following details of the operations against the cotton worm :
Operations for the destruction of the cotton worm have continued daring the weak ending of the 11th inst. with the following results :—
Behera Province.—48,474 feddans in 8C9 village area have been declared infected. Of these 42,562 feddans have been cleared of the worm.
Sharkieb.—949 feddan9 in 37 village areas have been declared infected and 947 feddacs cleared.
Dakahlieh. - 10,129 feddans are infected in 149 village areas. 9,284 feddans have been cleared.
Paycum.—Only one feddan has been reported infected and has since been cleared.
Gh'arbieh.—8,448 feddans have been declared infected in 144 village area?. 7,500 feddans have been cleared.
Ghizeb.—3,766 feddans in 14 village areas have been declared inflated ; of these 3,681 have been cleared.
Galioabieh.-2,199 feddans in 70 village areas have been declared infected and have all been cleared.
Menonfieh.—3,691 feddans in 63 village areas have been i>. feuded j of there 3,200 have been cleared.
Minieb. — 11 feddans belonging to one village have keen cleared.
Assiont, Beni Sonef, and Ke ieh provinces are declared free from cotton worm.
Altogether, 77,969 feddans have been declared infected in 791 village areas, and 69,385 feddans cleared. A very good week's work.

div.head: EGYPT'S TRADE.
div.p: The imports for the past month showed a decided improvement on the figures of Jane, 1905, an increase of L.E. 193,015 being reported. The exports show a decrease—only L E. 940,588 against L.E. 1,316,611—bnt if the whole period, from January 1 to Jane 30, is taken into consideration, the results in both exports and imports mast be pronounced highly satisfactory. The imports total in the first half of 1905 L.E. 10,513,579, against L.E. 9,427,986, the exports LE. 11,154,66^, against L.E 9,609,952. The increase, roughly amounting to a million in one case and to a million and a half in the other, is remarkably high. The figures for goods re exported daring the half-year amount to L.E. 231,932, an increase of L.E. 67,392, and a slight increase is noticeable in the total for goods in transit.

For the month there is an increase amounting to L.E. 115,349 in British imports and a decided decrease (L.E. 54,106) in the total of exports. British trade has, however, no reason to c explain of the last half-year, daring which our imports have risen to L.E. 3,458,443, against LB. 3,143,862 in the corresponding period of 1905, and the exports from Egypt to Great Britain to L.E. 5,592,473, against L.E. 4,756,248.

In comparing the June import and export figures of other countries with those of previous years, we note no remarkable changes except in the case of Russia. Imports from that country—which, as oar readers are aware, arrive in aiment every case from the Black Sea ports—only amounted to L.E. 7,907, about one-sixth of their total in Jane 1905.

In the export column there is a remarkable fall in the value of goods exported to .Fiance — L.E. 57,673 against L E. 178,994 in 1905— which we should like to see explained. But exports are low throughout—a decrease more or less considerable being marked against Egypt in the case of nearly every country that appears in the comparative tables as an importer of Egyptian goods.

For the half year France follows Great Britain in the list of importers and the Ottoman Empire is a good third, Austria-Hungary, Belgium, Germany, and Italy coming next. In the export columns, Germany—now becoming an excellent customer—follows us with figures of L.E. 1,210,981, against L E. 866,774, in the first halt of 1905. France is second, Russia third, and four's comes the Austro Hungarian Empire.

In the import lists we note again an increase in imported cereals both for the month and the half year, and a still more remarkable increase in the imports of "metals and mitai goods"—due to the expansion of the rolling stook of the State Railways and the import of machinery.

The exports of cotton fell off daring the month as compared with June 1905 but the total value of the cotton exported between January 1 and Jane 30 of the present year shows a large increase—L.E. 9,118,035 against LE. 7,175,950 in the first half of 1905.

div.head: MANCHESTER GOODS TRADE.
div.p: The chief feature of the market throughout the month of Jane has been its lethargy, says toe Journal of the British Chamber of Commerce. Sales for immediate delivery have taken place on a very small scale, while prices have shown a decided tendency to droop in spite of the high level maintained in Manchester. Although arrivals have not been excessive, it is probable that stocks in importers' hands are heavier now than they were at the beginning of the month.

A partial explanation of this state of things lies in the fact that all the larger local dealers, with probably the majority of smaller ones, have little confidence in the maintenance of present rates. Manchester quotations are regarded as too high for a sixpenny basis. In other words, it is deemed that manufacturers are working with such an ample margin on the present value of raw cotton that they own well afford to reduce it, and probably will reduce it should the American crop later on give promise of abundance.

Dealers holding this view, and having already provided for their minimum requirement's for the season, are not likely to enter into further engagements before hearing something more about the pros^ ects of the approaching crop.

div.head: NEW AUSTRALIAN MAIL CONTRACT.
div.p: The new mail contract between the Commonwealth Government and Sir James Laing and Sons, of Sunderland, is published. The contract will be in force for a period of ten years. The time of transit from Brindisi to Adelaide will be 636 hours, against 696 hours under the present contract, which it replaces in February, H08. The price agreed upon is £125,600, with an increase for acceleration on the basis of actual increased expenditure.

The steamers will call at Port Said, Colombo, and Fremantle, will arrive at Adelaide on Saturdays, and leave there homewards on Fridays. Increased railway facilities will be provided to ensure earlier delivery of mails at Sydney and Brisbane The minimum tonnage of the steamers is to be 11,000, and speed 15 knots, They will fly the Commonwealth flag and employ white labor. Five tendon were received, and the one accepted was the lowest.
A clause is included allowing the determination of the agreement if Commonwealth shipping legislation diminishes the company's earnings or increases its expenses,

div.head: LOSS OF EGYPTIAN RELIC.
div.p: VIRGIN'S TREE" FALLS.

Egypt has lost a venerable relic. The "Virgin's Tree" at Matarieh fell on the 14th in9t. and for Borne time to come the pions and the curious will miss an object of great in tersest and holy associations. While there is no doubt that the sycamore of Matarieh was not the original tree which sheltered the Holy Family daring the flight to Egypt, tradition declares that it came from the same stook— having been raised from the sued of the original sycamore. Several descendants of the ''Virgin's Tree" are now in existence, and we hope to see the fallen tree replaced by one of its progeny.

div.head: SUDAN AND WIRELESS TELEGRAPHY.
div.p: The following is the text of the ordinance for constituting wireless telegraphy a monopoly of Government, issued by the Governor G moral of the Sadan ;—
1. This Ordinance may be cited as "The Wireless Telegraphy Ordinance 1906.

2. No person shall install or make use of any apparatus for wireless telegraphy or transmit or receive messages by means of any such apparatus within the Sudan except the Department of Telegraphs or a duly authorized officer or official of the Sudan Government unless such person is in possession of a special license in writing from the Governor General.

div.head: SUDAN GAZETTE.
div.p: Mr. W. H. McLean is appointed an Instructor, Education Department, to date 8/5/1906. Mr. J. M. Favell is appointed City Surveyor, Port Sudan, to date 15/5/1906.

div.head: ALHAMBRA THEATRE.
div.p: CARMEN.

Carmen has always a peculiar charm of its own for the opera-goer, an I there are few who have not witnessed with mixed feelings of pleasure and sorrow the unravelling of the old story of fickle love, gallantry, and deception, and finally shuddered at the tragic demise of the heartless coquette. In Signora C. Esposito Carmen has a pleasing exponent, and although lacking in vitality occasionally, her performance was a distinctly adoptable one. Signorina Esposito possesses a voice of excellent quality, which she knows well how to use. The same may also be said of Signorina Tina de Spada, who was very successful as Mioaela. Signor Arrighetti's Toreador received quite an ovation. The famous song was exceedingly well rendered, and was heartily encored As a whole, the production may be said to be a success. The chorus, though small, sing with effect, and the orchestra is all that said be desired. The absence of appropriate scenery, however, somewhat detracted from the absolute success of the performance. This was painterly apparent in the second act, and was a considerable handicap to the artistes concerned. Between the third and fourth acts of the opera, a series of Greek classical dances were given by Signora Artemis Colonna, who proved herself no tyro in the art of graceful posing. Attired in a classical costume of soft clinging silk, Signora Colonna treated us to a feast of sinuous evolutions ; each gesture was carefully studied, changing quickly from grave to gay, delightfully fresh and true to nature, at times weirdly picture que. Her performance was certainly a meritorious one and was heartily applauded. To night Faust will be staged. We on thoroughly recommend our patrons to pay the Alhambra a visit. An Italian dramatic company is shortly repeated to arrive at Alexandria and will give a series of twenty performances at the Alhambra.

div.p: Wo do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in o spirit of fair play to all, to permit —within certain necessary limits- free discussion.

div.head: SATISFACTORY EXAMINATION.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir,—I shall feel obliged if you will kindly insert the following notice in your valuable paper. Having been requested to examine the English classes at the Couvent of the Franciscan Nuns, No. 29, rue Nebi Danial, I have great pleasure in testifying that the girls passed most satisfactorily, and gave ample proof of the efficient tuition of the teacher, Miss Sande- lands, of the Berlitz School. F. Wulstan Holland, O. F. M. St. Catherine's Cathedral, Alexandria.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB.
The A. S. C. will hold Skye Meetings on the 18th August, 29th September, and 27th October.

The club's racing programme for 1907 has just been issued. There will be four big meetings next season. The First Summer Meeting has been fixed to take place on the 2 ;tb and 28th April, the Grand Prize of Alexandria of LB. 1,000 being run on the second day. The Second Summer Meeting will take plaoe on 6th May (Shem el Nessim) and 12'h May ; the Third Summer Meeting on the 24th and 26th May, and the Fourth Summer Meeting on the 8th and 10th June.
The following is the programme of the gymkhana to be held on the A. S. C. ground on Saturday, 28th inst., oommenoing at 4 p.m :—
Tent Peoging.—3 runs. 2 points for a hit, 3 for a draw, and 4 for a carry of 20 yards. Competitors must gallop and not drop their lance until within a length of peg.
Trotting Rack.—For Arabs. To be ridden from grand stand round flag and back to winning post Any horse breaking must pull up and turn round on the spot where he broke. Distance 3 farlongs.

Potato and Bucket Competition.—Each competitor to ride at fall gallop and drop a potato into each of three buckets placed at intervals. Three runs. Any competitor not riding at full gallop will be disqualified.

Whistling Coon Rack.—Gentleman to ran 60 yards, whistle tone to lady, who mast write the name of the tune on paper, and hand the paper to the gentleman. The latter, whose pony will be held by the sais, will ride round a post to the winning post The first in with the outroot answer wins.—Prize to the lady.
Bending Race.—Competitors to ride their ponies in and out a row of flags, turning round the end one and returning the same way. Heats of 3.
Polo Ball Race.—Round a selected coarse. Ia heats if necessary.
Post Entries.—Entrance fee to oover all events P.T. 20. Ponies must be ridden by members of K. S. C. and A. S. C. Prise for eaoh race Objet d'Art.

div.head: CRICKET.
div.p: ALEXANDRIA V. RAMLEH.

Played on the A.C.C. ground yesterday, and easily won by Alexandria. The Town XI. won the toss, and Graves and Anbrey, aided by a good deal of luck, put on 68 for the first wicket,when Aubrey was run oat through a bad call and a fine piece of fielding by W. B. Peel Graves was bowled at 97 for a distinctly lucky innings and Marsden and Carver then nude a long stand, both scoring very freely all round the wicket Carver gave one chance which three fieldsmen might have reached, and none aooep- te 1, but his innings was otherwise marked by a number of very good strokes all round the wicket. Dawson, Dealtry, and Soartb hit with great vigor at the dose of the innings. The Ramleh batsmen could not play Mnstard, and with 6 wickets down for 13 a record minimum for Alexandria cricket seemed assured, bat Bailey and Merewether improved matters, the latter falling in the end to a magnificent oatob. Mustard took six wickets for 34. For the losing side W. E. Peel worked very hard in the field, saving any number of runs. The wicket bumped atrociously and a really fast bowler would have done great physical damage. Scores and analysis :—

div.head: EXTRACTS FROM HOME PAPERS.
div.p: After the wonderful demonstration of Saturday, by which Birmingham celebrated the ovoid virtues and achievements of her most distinguished otitis, comes the equally re- mark able demonstration of yesterday in honor of the thirty years of strenuous Paralimentary activity which Mr. Chamberlain has devoted to national and Imperial labors. There has been no antithesis in Mr. Chamberlain's thoughts or actions between these two things. His Imperial policy has grown out of his municipal policy, and his Imperial labors have never diminished his interest and his influence in the affairs of Birmingham, though they have inevitably involved devolution of actual administrative work. His home has always been in Birmingham, his affections have always been entered there, the people of Birmingham are his people, and in their unswerving trust and affection he has found ample cousolation and support in every vioiBBitude. ("Times.")

Mr. Chamberlain has often been charged with the recklessness of a demagogue, in that, after the conferences of Colonial Premiers in July, 1902—just four years sinc3—be drove the wedge of Tarif! Reform into the heart of politics. But a demagogue is one which seeks popularity with the mass of the people on any excuse. No one denies Mr. Cham berlain's astuteness ; and it cat hardly be contended that he did not foresee that the exact contrary of a wide popularity must ensue as the immediate consequent of bid straightforward advocacy of Tariff Reform. ("Standard.")

It is ill joking with an angry people, and the Russian autocracy may have to pay dearly for a piece of bitter irony which it has just perpetrated through the official organ of the army. The Imperial thanks are solemnly awarded to the troops for their "splendid service, and their glorious, self-sacrificing, nntiring, just, and honest devotion to duty daring the Bielostok pogrom." As the troops were employed in abetting the massacre, instead of restraining it, Russia will fully understand the inference to be draw as to the aspirations of her humane rulers, and will know what value to place upon the official versions of similar occurrences. Such a proclamation is not unlikely to live longer than its authors. ("Pall Mall Gazette.")

arrangement whi;h Sir E. Grey ha) canola del with France and Italy regarding the railways of Abyssinia is seedily increased by the news that it has been formally communicated to Germany. Germany has few interests in this part of Africa, bat she does none the less watch it attentively. Her complaint that the Moroccan Agreement was not form illy communicated to her was not without a basis, and this evidence of goodwill is a precedent which may, one hopes, establish a salutary tradition in diplomatic secrecy. To abolish the dread of on- divulged danses and unfavorable treaties would be to remove one of the most fruitful roots of Buspioion and nervousness in international relations. ('Tribune.")

The Attorney General seems anxious to apologies. He states that he did not say that judicial humor "invariably" occupied a low place in the order of wit, but "proverbially." In that case Sir Lawson Walton was quite wrong. There is no proverb on the subject, unless it be, "It's a puir judicial jock that disna mak' the loser laugh" ; and this we have just invented ourselves. ("Globe.")

"It is to be hoped that the happy days spent by Germans and Britons in common on British soil will result in bringing the national characteristics of the two peoples nearer to a mutual understanding." ("North German Gazette")

At first the Syrians rolled their eyes heaven- ward in holy horror at the thought of un- married young girls nursing men and attending operations, and they opened their eyes wide when they met me after entertainments in evening dress, and saw me ride a bicycle. It was _ indeed a new way of nursing the siok— to Bhow the devotion, the humility, and sacrifice of a nnm, and yet not be a consecrated woman. (Edla Wortabet in 'The N arising Times. ')

Nobody can make London believe that every American man here is not a millionaire. The old oak furniture factories in Yorkshire and Belgium are now working overtime turning out treasures for American millionaires. Of they, the most popular this season is the mohair in which King Charles I. sat daring his trial by Parliament. Three thousand of these ohairs have been made and sold already. ("New York World")

A new craze has arisen ; a new health cure, a new sporting sensation—ballooning, and a most excellent pastime it is. The Aerial Derby, which was run on Saturday, was in every way a great Buoaess, and in a short time doubtless, it will quite supersede motoring as the oorreot thing, as motoring did bicycling and bicycling riding. ("The Observer.")

div.head: CAIRO WATER SUPPLY.
div.p: En E trope, on n'hésite plus d'ntiliser poar l'alimentation des villes des eaux de la nappe profonde^çontenant de l'amoniaque. Ainsi par exemple, l'eau qui sert pour le nouvel approvi- sionnemeut de la ville de Berlin contient 0.28 milligrammes d'ammoniaque par litre. Cette eau provient de puits profonds de 40 mètres situés dans une forêt très loin de la ville de Berlin.

Si l'ammoniaque des puits de R)d El Parag devait son origine à une aspiration de l'eau du sous-sol de la ville, aspiration qu'on pourrait s'imaginer d'être causée par le puisage prolongé de grandes quantités d'eau, il faudrait que cette aspiration s'aocutât plutôt par l'augmen- tation de la quantité de chlorures et la rnagaé- sie et d'autres constituants qui se trouvent dans l'eau souterraine de la ville ea quantité infiniment plus considérable que l'ammoniaque Mais telle augmentation ne put jamais être constatée comme il résulte olairement du ta bleau des a ialyses.

Pendant les trois ans qu'on a puisé l'ean des puits n° 1 et 2, la quantité de chlorure est restée absolument oonstante, sauf des oscilla- tions miaimes qui sont dues à des oauses à expliquer plus tard. Da reste, aussi la quantité de l'ammoniaque n'a-t elle pas augmenté depuis la mise en fonction des puits, mais a montré elle aussi seulemeut des oscillations insigni- fiantes.

Du reste, une aspiration de l'eau souterraine de la ville, aus-i bien qu'une contamination de la nappe par les germes pathogènes provenant des infiltrations qui pourraient avoir lieu à proxmité des pdite, doit être oonsidérée com- me impossible à cause d'un rayon d'action très restreint das puits, de la configuration du sol, qui constitue un milieu filtrant de toot pre- mier ordre et de la profondeur deacouohes aquifères qui est de 30 à 60 mètrei au-dessous de la surface.
Il a é'é parlé plas haut de légères oscillations observées pour la composition de l'eau des pnits.

Cas oseillatioas s'accusent par one augmen tation ou diminution périodique du résida total et du degré hydrotimétrique (ohanx, magnésie, acide sulfarique). En général, on observe que pendant le temps de l'étiage le résida total et le degré hydrotimétrique sont un peu plus élevés que pendant ie temps du haut Nil, oomme il résulte olairement des n° 1, 2, 3 et 4.

Les analysée No*. 5 et 6 da puits No. 11 ne se prêtent pas à la comparaison parce que l'analyse No. 3 a été faite trop peu de temps après la m:so en fonction du pnit avant que l'état stationnaire du courant soa- terrain ne fut établi.
Pour le puits No. 2, nous observons dono plutôt une amélioration de la quantité de l'eau pendant l'étiage après deux ans de puisement oontinuel.
Les oscillations observées du résidu total et du degré hydrotimétrique sont du à la même cause qne les oscillatious beaucoup plus fortes o'o3e?vées pour l'eau du Nil.

On peut oonsidé er l'eau des paits cornue une eau ayant la même origine que celle du Ni1, c'eH-à dire, comme une eau du Nil filtrée naturellement à travers les oaucheî du so'. Cette filtration n'a pas lieu à proximité du puits; mais, ainsi qu'il résulte des différences de l'analyse ohimique et de la température constante de l'eiu des puits (température égale h la moyenne de l'année), l'eau doit avoir fait déjà un voyage assez long dans les couches du sous-sol.
Elle est donc, pour ainsi dire, l'eau d'on Nil souterrain qui accompagne le Nil super- ficiel et qui a la même origine que lui et se déverse finalement comme lui dans la mer.

Pendant ce séjour dans les couches du sol l'eau dissout une certaine quantité des matières minérales qui constituent le sol. Il est clair que la quantité des msftières dissoutes doit être d'autant plus forte qae l'eau reste plus longtemps en contact avec les couches du sol. Or, pendant la crue, la vitesse du oourant souterrain aussi bien que celle du Nil super- ficiel augmente, de manière que l'eau peut exercer eon aotion dissolvante sur les matières minérales du sol penrj^nt on temps moins long.

Le goût de l'eau du Nil ne diffère pas sensi- blemeut de celai de l'eau des puits. Il est im possible, pour la plupart des personnes et précisément pour les indigènes de distinguer hveo sûreté les deux eaux entre elles, comme j'ai pu le constater par nombre d'expériences directes.

Da toutos les observations faites sur les eaux des puits d'essai n° 1 et 2, il résultait donc clairement que la quantité de l'eau était excel- lente sous tous les points de vue. Comme il n'y avait pas à oraindre que la quantité ne soit pas suffisante on était donc tout justifié de baser l'approvisionnement de la ville du Caire sur l'eau de la nappe existant sous le terrain j-itné entre les puits n' 1 et 2.

Un certain nombre de nouveaux puits furent doue forés. Au mois de juillet 1905, cinq d'dntrV*x, réunis par un syphon, purent être mis en fonction, et l'eau provenant de ces puits (20,000 mètres cubes en 24 Inares) put être livrée à la consommation en ville pour rempla- cer l'eau filtrée du Nil.
Les pnits n 1 et 2 furent, pour des raisons techniques, provisoirement mis hors fonction.
Depuis le mois de juillet 1905 jusqu'aojour- d'h ii ces oinq nouveaux puits ont travaillé continuellement jour et nuit et fourni l'eau à la ville.
Quant à la composition de l'eau provenant de ces puits, elle ne diffère pas sensiblement de celle des puits primitifs, dont on peut se rendre compte en oomparant. les analyses no"
1 à 6 à celles n° 7 à 12. La quantité du résida fixe et le degré hydrotimétriqae correspondent presque exactement à ceux trouvés! pendant le temps de l'étiage pour le puits no" 1.

Depuis le mois de novembre 1905,'l'analyse de l'eau fournie par les puits a été faite ré- gulièrement ohaque mois, et l'eau n'a pas subi de changement sauf une légère augmentation du degré hydrotimétrique due aux osoillatiouB périodiques mentionnées plus haut.
Peu de temps après qu'il fut coonu par le publio que la Compagnie des Baux fournissait de l'eau de puits au lieu de l'eau du Nil, des plaintes différentes ont é'é formulées contre la nouvelle eau.

On l'accusait et on l'accuse encore d'être lourde et indigeste et de mauvais goût, de ne pas être apte pour les usages ménagers et iudastriels parce qu'elle serait trop dure et par conséquent ferait obstaole au savonnage, ouirait mal les légomes et incrusterait et atta- querait les ohaudières à vapeur.
Enfin qlle serait impropre à la lessive paroe qu'elle jaunit et tache le linge.
La plupart de ces accusations sont très mal fondées.

Le goût de l'eau ne diffère pas très sensible- ment de celui de l'eau du Nil, comme je l'ai mentionné déjà plus haut. Aussi beaucoup de personnes qui ne boivent que de l'eau ont assuré qu'ils trouvent le g ût de l'eau excel- lent.
Il n'y a pas la moindre raison qui pourrait rendre l'eau lourde et indigeste.

Il n'y a point de substances nuisibles la santé dans l'eau des pnits. La légère élévation, vis-à-vis de l'eau du Nil, du degré hydrotimé- tr'que no peut pas non plus causer d'indiges- tion, paroe que cette é évation se tient dans des limites très restreintes et, oomme il résulte des tableaux annexé1, la plupart des grandes villes d'Europe a une eau de dare'é égale ou même supérieure.
L'influence du degré hydrotimétrique plus élévé n'a pas d'iufluenco sensible sur la con- sommation de savon.
Le savon, avec l'eau de puit, mousse aussi bien qu'avec l'eau du NJ, comme on peut le constater tous les jours si l'on veut.

Les chaudières ne sont pas attaquées par l'eau du puits et la formation d'écailles n'a pas lieu dans des proportions inquiétantes. Au contraire, le dépôt formé dans les chaudières par l'eau des puit3, tout en étant plus volumi- neux, est moins dur et moins adhérant aux parois de la chaudière que le dépôt formé par l'eau du Nil.
Il ne reste dono que la plainte très souvent répétée que l'eau jaunit et tache le linge à la lessive.

Depuis que l'eau deB puits est distribuée en ville, l'eau prise au robinets des maisons oontient souvent plus ou moins d'oxyde de fer en suspension qui, tout eu n'étaut nuisible à la santé, doit exercer certainement un effet jaunissant sur le linge, mais il y a toute raison de oroire que oet oxyde de fer, qui se trouve en plus grande quanti'é et plus régulièrement dans certains quartiers de la ville que dans d'autres, ne provient pas de l'eau elle même, mais est détaohé des parois des tuyaux et oonduits incrustés plus ou moins de rouille. Ce détaohement est dû suivant touts probabi lité, à une augmentation générale et à des variations souvent très brusques de la prei-ion de l'eau, inoonvenient qui, jpour des raisons techniques, va encore persister foroement pendant un certain temps. Cette question de fer est sérieusement étudiée en oe moment par les Services Sanitaires et pir la Compagnie des Eaux et il y a lieu d'espé-er qu'on remé- diera à cet inconvénient dans le plus bref délai possible.

Dans les maisons on peut du res'e facile- ment débarrasser l'eau de l'oxyde de fer qu'elle contient en suspension, eu la filtrant à travers une couche de coton hydrophile qni retient tout le fer sans trop amoindrir la pression de l'eau.
La Compagnie des Eaux s'ooonpe de cons- truire un modèle simple de filtre à ooton qu'on pourra fixer directement au robinet. Il est à espérer que ce filtre pourra être bientôt livré au publio.

Le Vice-President,

div.head: PIGEON-PIE.
div.p: THE NEW EGYPTIAN CRISIS.
(Harold Spender in the "Daily Chronicle.")
Pigeons ! Why should a few pigeons have given rise to a tragedy that has shaken Egypt to its depths ?
Only those can understand who have taken the long river journey up the Nile.
Then yon find that the modern Egyptians revere their pigeons almost as piously as the anoients revered their oats.

As you journey you will pass by innumerable little villages built of sun-dried mud-bricks— so like to the soil in their colour that they almost seem to he moulded out of the Nile mud, and fated to orumble, like children's sand oastles, back into the ground that gave them birth. You weary of their sordid, careless Bhape —these dwelling plaoes of the fatalists. But there are two things that will always hold your eye. One is the little grove of (hading palms that waves above each group of Arab dwellings. The other is the pigeon-tower that always rises in the oentre.
It is a square, castellated structure, strongly built, and covered with blue earthenware tiles. It is fretted with little holes.

At first you think it is a fortress to protect the village, or perhaps the house of the head* man of the village —the "Omdeh," who still prospers under English rule. But then, per- haps, the steamer's whistle sounds, and sud- denly from the summit of the tower there rises a oloud of birds, white and blue winged, flash- ing in the sun kke beaten silver, or some fairy vision of floating, iridesoent opals. They circle and wheel round, but never fly far. Then they settle agaiD, and all is still, exoept per- haps for the far-off cry of some excited Arab boy. The village is left behind, and for miles you see no life exoipt soma lonely joggiog camel rider, or a torbaned greybeard with legs dangling low from his little white donkey.

It is computed that there are some ten mil- lions of these pigeons in Egypt, about one for every inhabitant. They are not kept for food, for they are rarely Bhot. They eat the seed and destroy the crops with a chartered free- dom. But the Egyptian peasant calmly en- dures it. His feeling towards the pigeon seems to have some curious, nntraced connection with the oldest religion of the country—just as he still reveres his ancestors, and visits their tombs with a piety which is not merely Maho- medan.
CONFLICTING IDEAS.

Like most pious people, he has to com- promise with life. There are men — rioh Egyptians as well as infidel dogs—who want to shoot pigeons. Such desires most be recog- nised ; you must meet them half way. So the Egyptian distinguished between "wild" pigeons and "domestio" pigeons. The "domestic" pigeons are those that live in the square towers. He will not have them shot at any cost—any more than we like ont London pigeons to be shot. The wild pigeons are those which have strayed away and live at large. They can be shot, like common quails, which he will shoot with yon for s officient piastres on any day of the week. -Bat leave most be asked from the Omdeh of the village distriot within which yon are going to shoot. For the greater part of the land of Egypt is not held by landlords, like happy England, bat by small peasant proprietors, who do not regard their land as only existing for purposes of sport.

Here, then, is one of those small causes of friotion continually reonrring between the European resident and the native-a friotion of custom and habit, a conflict of idea. The English officer, thirsting for sport, and earn- ing it by hard work, with little else to fill his leisure, casts envious eyes on those great flncka of pigeons. He sees that they will be "better for thinning," is horrified at the waste and destruction t cmse, impatient of what seems to him an idle prejudice. He may not be always too particular about asking leave from a "damned nigger." He is in Egypt as a conqueror, and he does not like the bnsiness of asking leave. Ou the other hand, the peasants are every day emerging more rapidly from their old habits of servility, and putting on, thanks to our very own emancipating spirit, new manners of independence and self assertion.

Then, when a tragedy occurs, there comes the cry for "strong measures." Sitting in London, we all very rightly keep our heads ; but in almost all white men the conditions pre- vailing now in Egypt produce the same condi- tion of nerves. There is th i feeling that you are always ontnnmberel if it comes to a ques- tion of sheer physical force—there is a'ways lurking behind the desperate fear that comes on the strongest men in face of a savage crowd —the fear of being submerged, overwhelmed. Lord Cromer has had constantly to fight against this fear in Egypt-, and there is always some danger of its getting the npper hand. It is not the Englishman, as a rule, who shouts loudest. It is the Frenchman, the Italian, and the Greek, who oall for strong measures. They oomplain that the Egyptian is getting "uppish." They dwell fondly on the "old days'' when every European oould wallop bis own native. And then when the native hits them back they fly to their owu Consulates and complain of the British Government.
LORD CROMER'S TASK.

Lord Cromer has a difficult task, and must not be judged too hastily. He has at his side the offended pride of the British military people, who see in this episode a disgrace and a slur to their uniform. He has to face an outburst of accumulated wrath against his polioy of leniency and equality, hitherto pur- sued without flinching. He has behind him a Ministry suffering from the long strain of the Turkish crisis. He has himself treated the fellah so well—so of'.en punished Englishmen for striking them and defended their village rights—that he may feel a little just wrath at this murder. The tribunal which tried these men was made up of the best lawyers in Egypt, and it would have been a serious thing for Lord Cromer to have overruled them. It would have left him alone. And the strongest man cannot role an alien raoe of ten millions alone.

It is a common thing on the Upper Nile to meet a greybeard who will boast of the num- ber of floggings he hadiat the hands of the old Khédivial GovernmentJHa took it in place of taxes. It was his form of "passive reeistanoe." He will go on to oomplain that now hi has to pay his taxes without the possible alter- native of being flogged. It is good that ha cannot be flogged; but his tak brings home to you that he does not taka the same view of the manner as you do.

But one thing is good—the pigeon-shooting is to be stopped. It is high time. On trifles— let us remember ihat trite and aucient saying — great issues turn. G e\se produoed the Indian Mutiny. It is not worth our while to risk the peace of Egypt for the sake of pigeon pie.

div.head: SYRIA-OTTOMAN RAILWAY SCHEME.
div.p: THE BANKRUPTCY OF MR. PILLING.

An application was made to Mr. Justice Bighsrn, Bitting last week as Bankruptcy Judge in the King's Benoh Division, for directions regarding a compromise proposed to be made by the troBtee under the bankruptcy of J. R. Pilling, the promoter of the Syria-Ottoman Railway Company and several subsidiary com- panies. In 1890 Mr. Pilling obtained a conces- sion for a railway from Acre to Damasons, and promoted the Syria-Ottoman Railway Company, in Turkey, the Syria Ottoman Railway Com- pany, Limited, in England, the Bank of Syria, and several subsidiary companies. Mr. Pillirg was made bankrupt in 1898, and the compa- nies went into liquidation.

Mr. Clayton, for Mr. F. S. Salaman (the trustee under the bankruptcy), said the appli- cation was that the trustee might be at liberty to compromise all olaims against the offioial liquidators of the companies in question by accepting £8,500. The bankrupt, althongh he had no power to interfere with the administra- tion of his estate, objected to it, on the ground that it was throwing away his property, and that the amount to be paid onght to be very mnoh larger. The trustee only desired to be protected against any fatnre actions.

Mr. Lash, K.C., for the bankrupt, submitted that the trustee had not the materials with which to arrive at the proper amount of the compromise. There was a sum of £130,000 in court, and of that sum the bankrupt olaimed no le3s than £103,000 as his interest in the oonstruotion scheme, less the amount of the mortgages and enoumbrauoes oharged thereon, and the amount of which had yet to be ascer- tained.

Mr. Justice Bigham said this matter came before him under Ssotion 89, Sub Saotion 3, of the Aot of 1883, which provided that the trustee might apply to the court for directions in relation to auy particular matter arising out of a bankruptcy. There was no obligation on the court to give directions, and in this oase he did not propose to give any. The oiroom- stanoes whioh were put forward in support of the compromise wire extremely oomplioated and d tficnlt to understand. They were exaotly the kind > the consideration of whioh, in his opinion, the trustee himielfhught to deal with, with the assistance of the committee of inspec- tion.
On the question of costs, His Lordship ordered the trustee's costs to be paid out of the estate. He did not think the motion wonld have been launched bat for the aotion of the bankrupt.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: General Sir Arobibald Hanter, whose three years term of command of the Western Com- mand in India will expire on September 3, has been granted an extension for one year.

Colonel Q.F.Gorringe, C.M.G., D.S.O., R.E., has joined at headquarters and taken ap daty as Direotor of Movements and Quartering, with the rank of Brigadier-General, on appointment in snooession to Brigadier-General H. M. Law- son, C.B., A.D.C., R.E.
Captain Peroy M. Dove, Notts and Derby Regiment, has been seconded for servioe with the Egyptian Army.
Lieatenant R. F. B. Knox, R >yal Dublin Fusiliers, has been seoonded for servioe under the Colonial Office, in the nsnal coarse.
Lieatenant F. L. W. Edwards, King's Royal Rifle Corps, has taken over the adj utanoy of the 4th Battalion, in snooession to Captain H. Wake, D.S.O., whose term has expired.

When the 1st Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers leave Ballykinler Camp on the 15th September next, it will prooeed on a regi- mental march of 15 days duration through parts of the Counties of Down and Antrim.

Last week the sergeants' mess of the Innis- killings presented a silver challenge oup to the sergeants' mess of the North of Ireland Imperial Yeomanry at Ballykinler, where the two regi- ments were together in camp. Mr. Bleakley, regimental sergeant major, presided, and made the presentation. The oup, which is in the f orm of an ancient Irish mether, was received by Mr. Pittaway, regimental sergeant major, on behalf of his mess. The cup is to be shot for annually at 200, 500 and 600 yards, and one of the conditions is, that the 1st Innis- killings are to be acquainted with the name of the winner, no matter in what part of the Empire they are serving. The presentation was made for the purpose of perpetuating the kindly feelings which have existed between the two regiments. The 2nd Battalion of the Inniskillings at Cairo will be pleased to learn of this.
The command of the Egmont, flagship of the Admiral Superintendent at Malta Dock- yard, has been given to Commander R. G. Gregory.
The battleship Implacable was paid off yesterday at Devonport, and re commissioned to-day at the same port for another tonr of service with the Mediterranean Fleet

The new first-olass croiser Shannon will be lannohedat Chatham abontthe 20'h Septembe next. The orniser is of the Minotaur type, and will, when completed, have a displacement of 14,600 tons, a speed of 23 knots and an arma- ment of fonr 9 2 inch guns, ten 7.5 guns and 30 smaller quiokflrers. She is one of a trio, the others being the Defenoe and the Minotaur.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
div.p: (Commuiiication Officielle)
La Délégation Municipale s'est réunie le 17 juillet 1906 à 5 b. p.m. sous la présidence de M. le Dr. Sohiess Pacha.
Présents MM. Barbaza, Mansonr Bey Yom- sef, Ra'.li, Sclimau Bey Abani et G. Z îrvu lachi, membres, I. Sadky Bey, secrétaire.
Li Délégation autorise à titre provisoire et révocable M. Michele Cosmaï à installer one glissière movible snr la cale sèche de Kaït Bey, destinée \ faciliter le halage des bâfeanx de pêche.
Elle décide l'établissement d'nne oanalis» lion poor l'éaoulemout des eaux de l'nrinoir situé dans la rue Mxitonoh Pacha et approuve la dépense y relative.
La Délégation prend connaissance de l'avis émis par le Comité spéoial an sujet de la règle- mentation de la navigation do canal M'h- mondieh et en ajourne l'étude à la rentrée.
Elle décide de demander à la Compagnie des Eaux d'installer des bouches d'incendie à Ramleh suivant i'état communiqué par le chef officier de la brigade des pompiers.

La Délégation décide de demander l'avis da service technique, surtout au point de vue des inta'.lations éleotriques aériennes on autres, au sujet d'une de demande de la ''The Egyptiau Fire Protection Co. Ld." tendant à établir un un poste central à Minet el Bassal pou l'ex- ploitation de son système d'avertisseur d'in- cendie.

Las promoteurs do la question des construc- tions à ,bon marohé ayant communiqué à la Munioipàlité les plans relatif à l'établissement d'nne oité ouvrière,. la Délégation sur la pro- position, da Comité spécial ohargé de oette étude, décide d'en iuformer le Ministère en le priant de vouloir bien donner nne solation à cette question par la cession à prix réduits des terrains sollioités pour oea constructions.

La Délégation émet un avis favorable à la note de l'Ingéaiear en ohef au sujet de la lar- geur à donner à la Corniche et adopte l'empla- cement proposé pour le dépôt des pierres destinées cette promenade.
Elle prend note d'nne lettre de la Compagnie des Emx informant qie la pose de tuyaux d'eau filtrée à Ramleh sera terminée an mois d'août proohain.

Vu la requête des marchands de pastèques, la Délégation demande aux services d'étudier le plus vite possible la question du ohoix d'un emplacement sur les quais, le plus près pos- sible de. Kaït Bey, pour servir de.dépôts pour les pastèques, oet emplacement devant être donné en location anx dits marchands.

La Délégation proposera à la Commission de déléguer Mr. le Dr. Gstsohlioh, inspecteur sanitaire, pour représenter la Municipalité au Urne congrès international d'assainissement et de salubrité de l'habitation, qui se réunira à Genève du 4 au 10 septembre 1909.
La séance est levée à 8 h. p.m.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Mardi 17 Juillet 1906.
A Londres, hier, le Consolidé anglais es' resté invarié à 88 7/8, de même que toutes le- valeurs égyptiennes à leurs cours précédents.
A Paris également, le Cré dit Foncier Egypt- ien et la Banque d'Athènes sont demeuré* immobiles à 751 et 150.

An début de la séance de ce matin, notre marohé des valeurs a montré nne certaine animation, qui n'a pas tardé à faire place au oalme inhérent à la saison. Toutefois les bonnes dispositions ont prévalu et on peut enregistrer nne amélioration dans la tenne génér-ile de la cote.

La National Bank a progressé à 25 5/16 L'Agricole s'est maintenue à 9 9/1G5/8. Lu Cassa di Sconto a avancé à 218 1;2 l'action ancienne et V12 la nouvelle. La Banque d'A- thènes a été traitée, ex coupon, à 147. La Banque d'CKient s'est raffermie à 132-133.
L'action Crédit Foncier s'est alourdie à 75f; l'obligation-à lots 1886 est revenue à 326 327 et la nouvelle à 271.
L'action Immobilière a gagné 4 francs 368 369 ; la part de fondateur, poursuivant son mouvement ascensionnel, a atteint 660 665.
L'action Entreprises et Travaux a été l'objet d'une bonne demande à' 4. L'Euterprise and Development s'est insorite à T 2. La part de fondateur Allotment est remontée à 122.
Le Wardan Estate a faibli à 6. La Frigori- fique a étéo^tée à 4 3/4-13/16.
Les actions de oapital Eaux du Caire ont fait 127-128 et les Jouissances 261.
La Delta Light^ç) é:é offerte à 11 3/4-13/1*. Les dividendes Tramways ont perdn 5 francs à 350. La Brasserie des Pyramides a progressé à 121.
Dans le groupa des Hôtels, lesNnngovich ont été pons'és à 15 5/8 11/16 et les Ezyptian (Baehler) à 5 11/16-3/4.

Parmi 1er petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont repris à 3 7/16 1/2. Les Estâtes, en bonne tenne, ont été largement traités à 1 3/4 ; la part de fondateur a gagné 1/4 à 10 7/16-1/2. Les Markets ont fléchi à 24 sh. Les New Egyptiau ont clôturé à 29 sh. 3 et 1er Cotton Mills à 5 sh. 9.
L'assemblés générale ordinaire de la Sooiété des Ciments d'Egypte a été tenue le 5 juil- let oonrant à Bruxelles sms la présidence de Chakour pacha.

Lss actionnaires ont approuvé le bilan de l'exeroioe 1905 et le compte des profits et pertes. Ils ont pris note de la démission de MM. J. Festa et A. Boeyé. MM. P.G Sohisas et Lefèvre on été nommés commissaires par acclamation.

Le président a déclaré qne l'expérience a démontré qne l'industrie était parfaitement viable et qu'à l'heure aotuelle la période des tâtonnements est passée. En 1906, la prodnotion atteindra environ 22,000 tonnes poor augmenter graduellement à 30 32,000 tonnes en 1907 et 36,000 tonnes les années subséquentes. Or, le maximnm de la pro- duction en 1904 avait été de l',000 tonnes.

Ghakour pacha,estime que l'exeroica 1906 ce laissera anottrr défi si t ; il pourra, au con- traire, donner nn excédent. Selon tontes prévisions, l'exercice 1907 permettra de distri- buer an dividende de 10 %. Si cette conjecture se réalise, la Suoiété sera dans nne situation financière splendide, et les actions iront nécessairement an-dessns du pair.
En ce qui oocoerne la demande d'admission des titres à la oote officielle de Bruxelles, le oonseil d'administration estime qae cette demande ne pent se produire qu'à l'occasion d'on bean bilan.

L'Egyptian Mdl Steamship Co., doat nous avons annoncé il y a qne'que temps la forma- tion, vient de commander à la Fairfield Ship- building and Ingln8eriog Co. la construction de denx grands paquebots-poste à turbines, ponr le service dos voyageurs entre l'Europe et l'Egypte.

Les journaux de Paris rapportent que, depnis le 4 juillet oonrant, les 30,000 obliga- tions nouvelles de 5 0 francs 3 1/2 ponr oent, No. 430,001 à 460,000 da Gré lit Fjncier Egyptien (émission 1934) sont admises aux négociations de lai Bourse de Paris, an comp- tant. \J
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

Les actionnaires de la Soc'été Egyptienne d'irrigation sont informés que le ooupon No. 10 sera mis en puiemmt k partir du 31 Jaillet oonrant, an siège sooial au Caire, ponr solde dn dividende de l'exercice 1905 1906. Let aotions No. 1 à 3,250 recevront 11 shellings ; les aotions 3,'251 4 4,250 recevront 16 shelling-.

div.head: CONDITION OF EGYPT
div.p: Professor Flinders Petrie oontribates to the "Standard" a lnoid statement of his views on the present nnrest in Egypt, in which he very accurately lays bare the failings of the fella- heen. He says :

The different opinions on the state of Egypt which yon pnt forward to-day, are in some points hardly less mischievous than Mr. Eeir Hardie's letter. People living at ease in Eng- land oan scarcely feel the pulse of native agitation abroad, and even the offioial classes abroad can hardly oome into tonoh with the thought around them. As 1 have lived in close contact with the Egyptian fellaheen during part of each year for a quarter of a century, I may venture to say that I agree thoroughly with your correspondent who has "lived a long time in Egypt." His views of the failings of the native seem entirely true.

During the past winter I have heard from different classes of residents, living in tocch with eduoated natives, exactly the same tale— the unrest, the olamonr to manage everything without any oontrol, and the risk of a serious revolution. All this results from oor admini- strators never having had a free hand in the management (f the country. And people who know nothing of Oriental mind or habits of thought, and are, therefore, incapable of real- ising the conditions, should oease their mis- chievous endeavours to tie the hands of those who oan learn on the spot what is required.

Apart from any external political influence there are causes of trouble in Egypt itself. Nations, like individuals, are naturally in- oapable of seeing their own defects ; and they require educating in self inspection. The growing incapacity of the native officials in Egypt has of late years been painfully appa- rent. Nepotism and personal favour is all- powerful. The railway and post services have slipped—at least in minor matters—into a scandalous state of mismanagement. Letters so frequently miscarry, or are mislaid, that it is usual for safety to telegraph when a le' ter is sent. The post boxes are habitually left unlocked in-one distriot that I have seen, so that any one oan take letters out. The Customs charges are not olaimed on parcels delivered. The railway tiokets are not issued in time, and an extensive system of travelling by bribing the guards and inspectors is habi- tual and well-known, even to European resi- dents. The delivery of third class tickets in Cairo is a scandal, a large part of the travel- lers being unable to get them in time for the trains.

Great delays are made in daily petty bosi ness, in order to extort bribes. The police system of ooHeotiog evidence is a mass of abase and oorrnption. And the native dootors are a terror, owing to their extortions. I am prepared to give exaot evidenoe on every one of these points, which have long been familiar and painfnlly so in recent years. The oanses of this deterioration from a somewhat better standard seem nndonbtedly to depend on the disappearance of the older generation of Eq- ropean-trained men. Each training at least made them aware of bnsiness habits j whereas the newer men, only brought up in the slaok air of an Egyptian offioe, are mnoh less capable. The remedy lies in a mnoh stricter train- ing. Bat this inoapable class are naturally nnable to realise better ways, and they as naturally want to do everything in their own fashion, and to oontrol the whole management. They aspire to get rid of the European heads, who are the only check on their nnlimited pillage of the country. And they are ready for any mischief which may lead in that way.

Repeatedly I have known of gross abases, which, when reported, were referred to native officials ; and in every case the native inquiry has solely heen directed to ooncooting an entire- ly false report, to throw blame on innocent parties. And this habitual lying has not been checked by any punishment for perjury. Jus- tice has become even rarer than it was, at any stage short of the English judge.

—. In saying all this the blame is not to be laid on the English controllers of the country. Their hands have been tied by a tangle of mischie- vous ohecks on their action. The ''susceptibi- lities'' of Europeans and of natives have been allowed to ohoke real reforms, and to foster a fool's paradise of immunity from natural oon- seqnences. Suoh and suoh a sop must be given to the Pashas, suoh a sop to the French, another sop to the Germans, and the real advance of administration has been almost stopped. The Copts are the most oapable and intelligent of the natives, but no Copt may rise to the highest offices, and a distinct ba- lance is given to the Mobamedan over the Copt in all oases of equality. The recent boom in Egyptian prosperity, entirely due to the far-reaching effects of English improvements iu administration, has upset the native mind, and given a feeling that they can fLurish without any help or check.

No doubt many persons of a hypertrophied oomcience in England f.el that we ought to leave a country to inanage its own aff tir», and the sooner we give over the fellaheen to be pillaged by the bnreancraoy the better. Yet such people are the first to ory oat that we should interfere in the affairs of Tarkey and of Russia, where we have no standing. If wo are to intervene between an ignorant peasantry and its corrnpt native rnlers in any ooontry, it mast certainly be done in Egypt, as in India,, before we throw stones at Tarkey or agitate about Russia.

The duty lies clear to our hands ; and we must remember that nothing but English occu- pation lies between the present prosperity of Ejtypt, and the bankruptcy and starvation under the native rule, from which we have elevated the country.

In an interview with a "Standard" repre- sentative on the snbjeot ot his letter, Professor Petrie was not inolined to recede from his attitude. He said, "I cannot speak about the unrest amongst Mahometan populations gene- rally, but I say, and I cannot put too great an emphasis upon it, that all the Europeans I have known in Egypt have felt this trouble coming on for a year past—this growing in- crease of difficulty with the natives. It has been obvious to us all.

"It does not exist in connection with the fellaheen so muoh as with the educated classes, because it is the latter who feel that we stand between them.and their making what they can out of the country, by the old, corrupt, methods. You must never lose sight of the fact that the fellaheen are extremely ignorant, fanatioal under the surface, and are a class easily stirred to mischief even when it is against their own interest. I have seen a great deal of the folly of the best and moEt intelli- gent of the fellaheen. The folly, the fickleness, the want cf solid sense amongst them is something extraordinary. They will propose a thing themselves, and the moment you make arrangements to fit the proposal, they will just ohange their minds, and propose, or wish for, something entirely different, and by the time you have made some fresh change to suit their convenience, they will very likely go back on their original proposa1. There is no stability in their ideas."

"I will give you an instance of this instability. For the past year th -y wanted a food supply, and requested me to make ar- rangements to get over some floor for them. I made arrangements accordingly, getting in large stocks, and preparing to let them bave it little by little as thsy wanted it. They ohanged their minds three or four times as to wheeher they would have it or not. Finally, they were thankful to receive it This was not through any objection or difficulty, but simply owing to their fickleness and want of foresight. And they are fickle in great things as in small. 1 honestly believe that, although you have lent them the money and have made their country prosperous, if they thought they could bring Egyptian stock down to 20 they would do it. It is perfectly hopeless for a person only accustomed to the motives that influence people in England to understand the situation amongst people who are totally impervious to those motives.

"We think in England that prosperity will make people oontented—though even here we have the proverb, 'Sat a beggar on horse- baok and he will ride to the devil' ! Prospe- rity, to the Oriental, only makes him dis- contented with everything that may be con- trary to his fauoy, and therefore it is that I oannot acoept the theory of those City financiers who say : 'The Egyptians are pros- perous, consequently there cannot be anything in these rumours of unrest. The native of Egypt is too sho-t-sighted to see from what ; oaases his prosperity comes. It is simply a ' cage of waxing fat and kioking.' I know ( myself that the better off a fellah is, the J more likely he is to be fanciful and uncertain 1 in his motives and his actions, and to judge hiS^by the motives which would irfluence business people in the Weet is the certain way to misunderstand him.

*'Yon aBk what I Wi uld suggest as a re- medy for the dangers ahead. Well, I, with a great many others, feel that it woold be well if Egypt were administered after the manner in which we administer India—that wonld mean a great change, I am aware, but drastio ohanges have been found neces- sary already.' In some instances, the native conrts, which were hopelessly corrupt, have had to be abolished, and replaced by a British resident magistrate, to the great satisfaction of the natives, who have openly said that 'now they wonld hope to get jnstioe.' "

In response to the question what the rest of Earope wonld think of the plan of governing Egypt on the model of India, Professor Flinders Petrie said, "It is hard to see how any interest of Earope ia Egypt could be anything bnt benefited by a more certain and decisive admi- nistration of the country. I know that in what I am now saying I have an Egyptian, as well as a British, audience, bat the time has oome to speak ont. We write and speak on these matters, indeed, as if we were addressing a body of natives, as it is qnite certain that the Arabio newspapers reproduce everything that ccmes from us which it is thought will be either an incentive to farther dislike of the Administration or damaging to the European. The European is becoming more and more unpopular in Egypt, and, to some extent, it is . his own fault. He mast teaoh himself to be J mnoh moio firm in his dealings with the , native, and at the same time, mnch more polite.

| I have to be firm myse'f. On one occasion I Lad to resort to personal violence to overcome a persistent poacher on one of my exploration fields. I prevailed over the man, and he respeoted me. I, alone and unarmed, met him ou a subsequent occasion in his native village. He walked behind ms at a distance of ten paces or so, and had nothing but words of comp'injent for me to his friends to whom ho pointed me oat as the man who had resisted him. We must be firm, but the manners of some Europeans must be improved.

" Unfortuoately, Europeans in the -East are too apt to fall into one or other of two extre- mes—namely, that of ignoring legitimate solf- respect and habits and thought amongst the nativis, or else of applying to them an entirely foreign standard of sentiment, and it is hard to say which of these two is the worse. The natives require to be ordered. Yoa must find out from the best and most sensible men amongst them what their publio opinion is, and aot on that as if it were yonr own idea. In that way you are sure not to hurt them."

Professor Flinders Petrie gave instances of "corruption, mendaoity, and hopeless chicanery" on the part of native officials in Egypt, and oonoluded by expressing regret that the British I administrators had never been able to aot sole- ly with a view to the welfare of the country and the real interests involved. Their hands bad always been tied in a manner be had set forth in his letter to "The Standard."

"The Daily Express" has received the follow- ing letter from the Rev. James Rose, who has just returned from missionary work in Egypt, where he has had exceptional opportunities of ascertaining the feeling among the natives :—

I can bear personal and painful testimony to the infinite mischief which is wrought in Egypt by the "irresponsible monthings" of certain gentlemen in the British House of Commons. Not only are English papers freely read in Egypt, but the native Press is quick to reproduce the ohoice morsels now so oom- monly found in the unpatriotic vaponrings of pnblio men.

The "Lewa." for example, a native Cairo daily, has a vioious reputation for this kind of work, and these welcome excerpts from the speeches of British (Î) politicians, plus the editor's own aoidulated comments thereupon, are served up as grateful pabulum for the native mind to feed upon. This paper, in particular, oiroolates in soil the native bazaars and cafés of tbe country, and is read with avidity by high and low.

Onoe let the followers of Islam get deluded with the insane idea that Great Britain is about equally divided in her ooonsels regard- ing Egypt, and the flag of universal revolt would be immediately unfarled.

During the recent aoute orisis with Turkey over the Akaba question we were within an ace of a general native rising! and thousands would have been massaored before it oould have been effectually suppressed.

Before suoh pseudo patriots in the British House of Commons open their lips of igno- ranoe upon the subjeot of Egypt, let them first study well the subjeot of Islam, and then, having delivered themselves of their diatribes, let them send their wives and children, if they have any—or, better still, go themselves—into some bigoted Mohamedan village of the in- terior far removed from the presence of British rifles and bayonets, and there quietly await the issue of their own brave words,
If they did, they would never have a ohanoe of repeating such criminal folly. But there are thousands of lives in Egypt to-day at the meroy of the Moslem.

div.head: TROUBLE FROM CAPE TO CAIRO.
div.p: What with the latest native outrages in Egypt, the spreading revolt of Natal Esffirs, the sustained resistance of the Hottentots to German role in the south-west, the fresh risings in German Nyassaland, varions Sudan Incidents, and continuons fighting in Nigeria, not to mention Sir Edward Grey's ominous comments as to the whole northern coast of Africa, we may look forward to fairly stirring times in the Dark Continent, as far as native troubles are concerned. It is, therefore, of speoial ioterest to note what the "Westminster Gazette"—always a oalm and jadioial observer on great occasions—thinks of the snbjeot. Oar contemporary oonsiders that, as far as the north is conoerned, the present African unrest is a Mobamedan nnrest rather than an Egyptian unrest, and no one oan dogmatise about its causes. These movements come and go and bring with them, waves of feeling which the people themselves cannot interpret. Possibly in the present oase the stimulating oause is the European entrance into Moroooc, which is resented as an incursion into one of the last strongholds of the faithful. All we see are the results, which manifest themselves in the demonstrations of the Saltan of Tarkey and in a oertain restlessness of the Moha- medan folk which leads to incidents like that of Deoishwai or to other less serious incidents like that reported from Alexandria. Then we are obliged to take punitive measures which inorease the exoitement, and so the thing goes on in a vicious oirole. "There is nothing to do except inorease oar garrisons, as we have just done, and talk as little as possible."
