div.head: EXCAVATIONS AT ESNA.
div.p: THE WORK OF THE LIVERPOOL UNIVERSITY EXPEDITION.

Mr. John Garstang gives in the ''Times'' some interesting particulars of the work accom- plished in Egypt by the expedition sent oat last antnmn by the Institute of Arohœilogy of Liverpool University. The objects discovered are now being exhibited in the oity museums of Liverpool, the exhibition being inaugurated last week by the Eul of Derby.

The explorations of which these antiquities are the outcome were, Mr. Qarstang states, cooduoted over a somewhat large traot of country, and the objects to be exhibited re- present several distinot periods of Egyptian history. In the first plaoe. the expedition resumed its work at Bans, and there completed the excavation of a site which has proved of considerable importance from the historical standpoint, inasmuch as it has provided what is possibly the most representative and com- plete series of Egyptian antiquities of the Hyksos period. The objects themselves are for the most part of a oharaoter which accords well with the provinoial situation of the ancient Latopolis ; but perhaps from that very cause they will prove of surer value to arobæology in that they illustrate the remains, both do- mestic and funerary, of the Egyptian people themselves rather than more attractive an- tiquities fashioned specially for the funerals of great offioials or Royal personages.

Meanwhile, daring the coarse of these ex- cavations, a systematic exploration had been made of the desert lying to the sonth of Esna for a distanoa of 60 miles. Most of the sites of antiquities had been very muoh disturbed, bat it ws possib'e to sift from them oartain slight evidences, which seemed to bear directly upon the problem of the origins of the Upper Egyptians. Following the clnes thus'indicated, the expedition moved oamp into the heart of N ubia in the hopes of there getting beyond the reaoh of modern plunderers and of being able possibly to distinguish by an examination of the arohæilogy of that region those features of the early Egyptian oulture which might be considered to be Afrioan rather than Asiatic in origin,

Exoavatloas were made at Kubban and at Dakke ; at both places something of interest was found, which will be desoribed in a speoial publication ; but the ohief interest was awaken- ed by the disoovery of an undisturbed necropolis near the anoient fortress of Eostamneh, which lies some five miles to the north of Dakke upon the west bank. Some 200 graves were excavated and a complete record made, with photographs and notes, of every feature of interest which they disclosed It may be said in brief that in many respects the objcots and funereal customs reveal a dose analogy with pre-dynastio and early dynastio people of Upper Egypt ; but, at the same time, many vases of pottery were found which seemed to resemble more closely those sporadio examples which are fonnd in- truding themselves into the Egyptian gTaves lower down the Nile during the 12th dynasty or thereabouts, and have been generally attri- buted by arobæ jlogists to a reiucursion of some element of the primeval population. These objects will all he exhibited during the coming weeks -, but it is hardly possible to say with- out further study, indeed without more evidecoe of a comparative oharaoter, to what preoise period in Egyptian history these must be assigned.

These discoveries open up a problem of first interest connected with the early days of the Egyptian civilisation, They suggest, in short, that possibly the primitive type of Egyptian oulture, as illustrated in the now familiar graves of pre-dynastio and archaio times in Central Egypt, may have survived in these remoter districts of Upper Egypt, not merely into the early historic phase after the founding of the monarchy, but far down into the dynasties, possibly even to the 12th dynasty or later. These considerations are considerably illuminated by the remarkable survivals in modern Nubia of many small features of the Egyptian civilization, which is illustrated even by the hairdressing of the girls and the manner in whioh the bread is prepared for baking.

The(exhibition will also oontain a series of interesting antiquities discovered during a month's tentative work at Abydos, to which place the expedition removed when the heat in N obia became too great for farther work. In this famous necropolis,from wb:ch,a distinguish- ed English explorer recently recovered the his- tory of Egypt's earliest kingp, there still remains some ten or 12 years' organized and systematic work. The anoient Abdu, throughout Egyptian history, remained a favourite burying-place for the wealthy and the pious, and mach history may be still recovered from its tnmbled-sands. It is this site that will probably form the centre of our work in the coming seasons.

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement
div.p: OF THE " Egyptian Gazette. "

The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Qezette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaust- ive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share market", with all the latest statistics op to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the oopies of the offioial telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt. For abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For further particulars apply to the Manager "Egyptian Gazette."

div.head: MOUNT TROODOS,
div.p: Cyprus.

A limited number of paying guests can be received by a Lady daring the Summer Months. Cyprus is 34 boars by sea from Port Said. Troodo3 6,406 feet above the sea is a delightful and healthy plaoe amongst the pine forests where the troops and Government Officials spend the hot season.
Terms 2$ Guineas per week.
For further particulars apply to Miss YOUNG,
Nikosia, or to the Editor-
Further Particulars.

Position. The pine covered slopes of Mount Troodos where Miss Young has a camp, are about 6406 feet above the sea ; the troops stationed in Cyprus and the Principal Government Officials live there during the hot season from about June till October. j

Routes. Troodos is about 35 miles from the port of Limassol from which there is a good carriage road to Plâtres 31 m. Beyond Plâtres the road is good but steep and from that point people often ride on mules for the - rest of the journey. There is also an excellent road frdra the Capital, Nicosia, by which persons going from that side of the Island drive all the way (about 16 miles).
Climate. The climate is very dry and healthy; in the daytime it is delightful ; the nights, especially after the end of August, are often rather cold.

Dress. There is a good deal of red dust on the hills, and ladies should be provided with washing skirts. White is a good deal worn, but it is advisable to have some ' brown, fawn, or dust-coloured linen dresses which do not shew dust stains as the washing is not first rate. A warm woollen "coat and skirt" costume is also indispensable.
Rides. There are plenty of delightful rides amongst the hills, but the roads and bridle paths are too steep for bicycles. Mules and ponies can be hired for the season.
Expeditions. Places of interest to be reached on mule or pony back are Kykko Monastery, Kalopanaioti, Trooditissa Monastery, etc.
Games. There is a Tennis Club with two good Courts, there are also one or two private tennis and croquet grounds.
Church. An English Church Service is held twice on Sundays at the Regimental Recreation Room.
Water. The water supply is good and the drinking water pure and wholesome.
Monet. Drafts on the Imperial Ottoman Bank and nglish gold and notes accepted.
By June the railway which runs from Famagusta to Nicosia will be extended to within 20 mile of Nikosia.
